segments.text: Hello and welcome to another edition of
TJ Plays with some A2 UI. So, in this
video, I thought I'd cover something
that's been generating a little bit of
buzz right now, both in the AI community
and the design systems community. And
it's called A2 UI. And in this video, I
hope to break it down into easily
digestible sections just so that way you
kind of understand completely what it is
both from like a designer standpoint,
from a infrastructure standpoint, from a
user standpoint, who's interacting with
it. And then I want to call out some
differences between some of the types of
code generators and ways these
components and layouts are generated
versus what this actually is because I
know there's a lot of confusion behind
or at least I'm hearing a lot of
confusion around what exactly is A2 UI.
So I think where I'll start is uh so
like the concept is like what if a AI
agent could build real user interfaces
not mockups or code snippets but like
real actual working components from your
design system on demand as part of a
conversation or an interaction and this
is in your production application. And
this isn't like a developer support tool
or something like that. So in a
nutshell, that's what A2UI enables. And
we feel really strongly about it only
because we've already started to begin
implementing this kind of like in a beta
version of some of the projects that
we're currently working in. So, we felt
the need to kind of show you some of the
work that we've been doing with it and
then explain to you the importance of it
and then where we think it's headed in
the future.
So just to address what we think the
current problem is with AI UI generation
is that currently right now when AI
agents need to show something more than
just text they usually resort to two or
three poor options or bad options.
First they can generate code using
claude or JPT or Gemini or whatever. It
writes your React. You can copy and
paste that React into your codebase. If
it has access to your codebase, then it
writes it directly to your codebase.
Maybe it works, maybe it doesn't. But
this is the key distinction. It can't
run arbitrary
generated code in production.
One, it's not something that you want to
do, but two, you need to test that. The
security issues, there's lots of
different reasons why you wouldn't want
that to happen. People talk about, you
know, the issues with risky AI
generations and hallucinations and just
the fidelity of component generations
and just code generation in general from
AI. So that's probably not something
that we want to do in production, just
letting AI run a muck in your production
environment. And so, uh, one of the
second things is they can describe what
to build. So like create a form with
three fields and a submit button. Cool.
Now you kind of need somebody to go and
hook it up to stuff. You need a
developer to implement it. It needs to
hook to an API. Needs to be integrated
within a CMS or whatever the use case is
for that component structure. Another
issue is they can use pre-built widgets,
but they're only they're limited to
whatever widget someone anticipates you
need. So there's really no flexibility.
So it's a predefined layout, so to
speak. So that it's like you can if
you're using tools to generate your
landing page or your homepage, they'll
always be your landing page or your
homepage. You can edit them and
republish them and maybe you can drag
and drop some things around, but that
requires a developer or an editor to go
in and make those edits. So it's limited
flexibility. A2 UI
is is mainly
looking to solve this problem.
A2UI solves this by separating what the
agent wants to show from how your
application renders it. So I'll get into
a little diagram
here. So this is the the A2 UI official
documentation site from Google and this
is like a little bit of a behind
thescenes look into what exactly it
does. The key insight is that A2UI is a
dec a
declarative protocol. The AI doesn't
generate the code. It generates a recipe
that lines up to the code. So, it's a
structured JSON description of what UI
elements should appear and how they're
arranged in the data they display. So,
your application then renders that
recipe using your own components. You
type whatever it is, type a message or
interact with a button or something
somewhere. And then there's an AI agent
that communicates with the language
model that then generates the JSON,
which is the recipe. And then that
recipe is hooked to your component, your
web application that serves your
component library, your design system.
It then serves up those components to
the user's UI. So the the user interface
that the user is interacting with based
on whatever their interaction was,
whatever the intention was of that user.
So why does this matter? know this
matters because when we're moving
forward into a world where AI agents
handle more complex tasks and this isn't
something that's going to be utilized in
every like this isn't probably something
meant for marketing websites or uh maybe
at some point they will but this is
mainly meant for UI heavy workflows that
have a lot of uh widgets and dashboards
and forms and mostly enterprise use
cases I think in the beginning is
probably what this would likely be used
for. But right now, the way that a lot
of this back and forth happens is
through chat bubbles. Basically, like
we've all used and claude and all these
other language model platforms and it's
a very much a back and forth repetitious
cycle of you ask a thing or you say a
thing, it responds with the thing and
then so on and so on and so on. So
imagine an enterprise agent that can
generate approval workflows or data
visualizations or custom forms based on
conversation context or customer service
agent that can show product comparisons
or booking interfaces or account
management screens without any pre-built
templates. So when Google released this
A2 UI as a open protocol because this is
the future that they see coming. So when
you ask things like some of the examples
that they supplied here, it's like book
a table for two. The user doesn't
understand components or understands
forms or what exactly they want to
display. They're not explicitly
describing what they need in order for
them to book a table for two. They're
saying book a table for two. in the
agent is generating a recipe that is
lining up to components or component
structures that have already been
predefined within your design system and
then delivers a date field, a username
field to log in potentially and how many
seats or how many people your
reservation. So that's kind of an
example of how that works. And uh I
think one of the biggest distinctions
that is important to make here is that
these are different like this is a
protocol for one. So it isn't like an
application that you're downloading. AUI
is like HTML. It's there's confined set
of constraints around the way these
recipes are built. It's not like
something like lovable or v 0 or bolt
tools like lovable or vzero. Those
already generate full applications from
natural language. But the big
distinction here, those are meant for
developers or designers who are looking
to dabble into code generation or
application generation. They generate
code that developer reviews that you
typically a developer would review and
deploy before going live. And then once
it's live, it's there. It's great for
prototyping, but they're not running
that output directly in a production
environment, especially without someone
taking a look at it. A2 UI is different
because it's a runtime protocol. That AI
generates a recipe, your application
renders it using your pre-approved
components, and real users see the
results, all without a developer in the
loop. So, this is happening live in your
application. And this isn't something
that's pre-built and then shipped or
deployed to an application. So, it's
different between AI helps me build an
app and AI shows users an interface
during a conversation. Both are very
valuable. Don't get me wrong. I think
they're both amazing pieces of
technology. They're just different
layers in the stack. So, I hope that
helps create the distinction there.
So, let me show you a little bit about
what ATUI actually looks like. So, I can
use uh the documentation site just to
kind of give you the anatomy of A2 UI
and what the quote unquote recipe looks
like. And this is basically what it is.
So, the AI is generating this recipe.
So, first it kind of it generates an ID.
So, this is the main ID. This is kind of
like establishing the global ID of the
UI that it's about to generate. And then
it is grabbing some identification
uh some some uh identification markers
that are syncing to components that
exist within your design system and then
it's filling those with the components
and then any of the properties that live
within those components. So it's putting
in the values like book your table. It's
saying grab the ID of date picker is
going to pull the datetime picker
datetime input and then the the values
that need to be filled in are these. And
then so there's other uh key value pairs
that it pulls through. But this is a
fairly simple example of what this might
look like for the restaurant reservation
book a table for two example. Uh and
we'll get into a little bit more of the
detail stuff. I don't want to get bogged
down in the code side of it uh too much,
but what's important to understand is
that uh it is uh some sort of user
input, whether it's an event that
happens that engages your agent, your AI
to generate the recipe based on A2UI's
predefined
guidelines. And then it's up to your
design system and how well your design
system has been defined to determine the
return the output what comes back from
the recipe that the AI has generated.
So, one of the things that I wanted to
make sure that we talk about why it's
such an important piece of technology
right now and how this ties in with
design systems is that now more than
ever is it important to increase the
fidelity of your design systems to
ensure that you've got documentation on
point that you've got full coverage of
all your components and component
structures. Because once these recipes
are created, these are the recipes that
are going to be looking for components
that should exist within your design
system and line them up so that way it
can create these compositions in order
to fulfill the user's intent. If it
doesn't find a certain component, your
AI will either move on to whatever the
next best thing is or it'll fail safely
and it won't error out or anything
depending on how your application works
with it. So, we've been doing some work
with this for a little bit. I can show
you a couple of examples of some things
that exist out there. For one, this is
the A2 UI. It's a public repository. You
can play with it. There's some demos in
here that you can mess around with. The
demos are mainly Angular in web
components with lit. I think in the
future are some um uh they're looking to
add React View and some other JavaScript
libraries and frameworks to it. But as
of right now, you can clone this and
play with some of the examples that they
have in there. They're good to play
with. And this is the official blog post
where they're introducing A2 UI. It's a
good read. It does a really good job
distilling some of the stuff that I just
mentioned, talking about the main
problems, how agents need to speak to
UI, not have this clunky back and forth
that happens with the I want to book a
table for two. Okay, what day? I want
that tomorrow. Okay, what time? Maybe
7:00 p.m. Oh, we don't have anything for
that. What other times? So, there's a
lot of back and forth that why not just
present the user with a form and then
allow them to do the interactive parts
themselves? Uh, one cool little tool
that I wanted to call out was this neat
A2 UI composer. So, you can just there's
a gallery of things that you can
actually pull from in here. So, there's
all these little card components and
then reasons why all these are created.
But then there's uh this create part.
So, you can say something like um I need
to book a flight from New Orleans,
Louisiana to New York on March 15, 2026.
And then I can create this. And this is
a fun little tool. This is powered by uh
Copilot Kit, which is uh like a a
partner of A2UI. They have a site here
that does a really good job of outlining
some of the specs and uh and then it
does a pretty deep dive into what
exactly A2 UI is and offers some
examples and demos and other fun stuff.
So, I'll link all of these in a in a
resources post and I'll post it along
with this message. As you can see right
here, this is a live example of
something that I posted. This is a
flight booking. This has the place where
I said the origin should be. And this
has the destination of where I'm looking
to go. It knew that I needed some sort
of uh date picker. Uh and then with the
book flight options, this is a little
primitive. It's not exactly like the
most uh aesthetic thing. And then over
here, it shows you the recipe or the
spec that the A2 UI spec that was
created. And then over here is the chat
interface that it heard from my input
and then how it ended up generating
this. And then if you wanted to apply
this to your application, you can copy
the JSON or you can download it
specifically and then add it if this is
something that you're looking to do. Uh
we have uh a similar tool that we've
been working on. Like I said, we've had
some projects that have called for this
type of technology. uh mainly for a lot
of security reasons and then just for
ensuring that there isn't any sort of
derailment of the AI when it's
generating these components. So we ended
up creating this thing called A2UI
bridge. Uh I'll show you in a second
about what it this is very similar to
the A2UI composer from uh the co-pilot
kit folks. Uh this one's ours. So I did
the same thing here. It's a chat
interface. I'm trying to book a flight
from uh New Orleans airport to uh New
York JFK on March 26, 2026. And then I
have right now A2UI's demo is only
limited to like I said before uh web
components with lit and angular I
believe it's using material and uh in
our projects we were mainly working with
shad CN or mantine as our as our design
systems. So, we needed to create this
bridge to do something similar to what's
in the A2UI GitHub repository to work
with React, which isn't something that's
currently supported. So, we needed to
figure out a way to get that bridge
connected and actually have it
supported. So, that's what this is here.
It's it's fairly simple and
straightforward. I did the same thing
here with this uh conversation chat. I
said, "Book me a flight." This is what
it rendered. And then you have the
option of going back and forth between
Shad Cien uh and Mantine. And as you can
see, it'll it'll put the actual airports
in there um for New York. And then
there's the datetime picker. And then
you could select your seats and all that
kind of stuff. And there's other ones.
There's these predefined scenarios. If
you ever wanted to use any of these, you
could uh like say you could doctor's
visit. So these are the predefined
scenarios. You don't have to go by any
of the ones that are in here. You can go
with just whatever you want to do. So
you can say like, I want to book a table
for two at my local Chinese food
restaurant. And then it would render
that for you. So here's the here's what
it generated. Um, and this is like
pretty spot-on for what you're looking
for. So imagine a world where you're
working within an application. Instead
of the response that you get from your
language model provider or whatever
language model you're working with,
you're getting the actual tool or
interface that is needed in order for
you to complete the thought or or finish
the action or whatever it is that you're
communicating with AI in the first
place. So I'll post this along our
resources. This gives a full explanation
of exactly what it does and what it is
and probably does a better job of
explaining what ati bridge is. It does
have mantina and shad cn adapter in it.
So if you didn't want to write your own
recipes, it comes with recipes that are
aligned with the properties from those
design systems. So you would just be
able to hook this up and it should work
right away. If you don't have that, then
you'd want to install the A2UI bridge
and then you'd want to start creating
your own adapters. So that way your A2UI
knows how to generate. Basically, you're
creating the guidelines for the recipes
that A2 UI would be generating or your
language model would be generating based
on the A2UI spec.
Anyway, that was a lot. Um, there's
another piece that I want to get into at
some point where we have this fun
playground where we get into these
experiments and uh, a lot of
documentation and just some really
interesting stuff that we've been doing
with A2UI. Uh, this is all publicly
accessible stuff and I'll be sharing all
of this. This is our A2UI lab where you
can really get into like a some really
like deep areas of A2UI and how it's
being used and how it renders and what's
happening on the back end. This is a
little technical for this conversation
and this is already a pretty lengthy
demo. So, I'll leave it right there and
say if you have any questions about
this, please feel free to reach out.
This is something that's near and dear
to us only because we've been kind of
consumed with it over the last couple of
weeks. And um and yeah, so uh I hope you
have a moment to look into it and and
like I said, if you're ever looking to
uh get a little bit more information
about this or or curious about what
we're doing with it, don't hesitate to
reach out. Thanks a lot everybody.

fullText: Hello and welcome to another edition of TJ Plays with some A2 UI. So, in this video, I thought I'd cover something that's been generating a little bit of buzz right now, both in the AI community and the design systems community. And it's called A2 UI. And in this video, I hope to break it down into easily digestible sections just so that way you kind of understand completely what it is both from like a designer standpoint, from a infrastructure standpoint, from a user standpoint, who's interacting with it. And then I want to call out some differences between some of the types of code generators and ways these components and layouts are generated versus what this actually is because I know there's a lot of confusion behind or at least I'm hearing a lot of confusion around what exactly is A2 UI. So I think where I'll start is uh so like the concept is like what if a AI agent could build real user interfaces not mockups or code snippets but like real actual working components from your design system on demand as part of a conversation or an interaction and this is in your production application. And this isn't like a developer support tool or something like that. So in a nutshell, that's what A2UI enables. And we feel really strongly about it only because we've already started to begin implementing this kind of like in a beta version of some of the projects that we're currently working in. So, we felt the need to kind of show you some of the work that we've been doing with it and then explain to you the importance of it and then where we think it's headed in the future. So just to address what we think the current problem is with AI UI generation is that currently right now when AI agents need to show something more than just text they usually resort to two or three poor options or bad options. First they can generate code using claude or JPT or Gemini or whatever. It writes your React. You can copy and paste that React into your codebase. If it has access to your codebase, then it writes it directly to your codebase. Maybe it works, maybe it doesn't. But this is the key distinction. It can't run arbitrary generated code in production. One, it's not something that you want to do, but two, you need to test that. The security issues, there's lots of different reasons why you wouldn't want that to happen. People talk about, you know, the issues with risky AI generations and hallucinations and just the fidelity of component generations and just code generation in general from AI. So that's probably not something that we want to do in production, just letting AI run a muck in your production environment. And so, uh, one of the second things is they can describe what to build. So like create a form with three fields and a submit button. Cool. Now you kind of need somebody to go and hook it up to stuff. You need a developer to implement it. It needs to hook to an API. Needs to be integrated within a CMS or whatever the use case is for that component structure. Another issue is they can use pre-built widgets, but they're only they're limited to whatever widget someone anticipates you need. So there's really no flexibility. So it's a predefined layout, so to speak. So that it's like you can if you're using tools to generate your landing page or your homepage, they'll always be your landing page or your homepage. You can edit them and republish them and maybe you can drag and drop some things around, but that requires a developer or an editor to go in and make those edits. So it's limited flexibility. A2 UI is is mainly looking to solve this problem. A2UI solves this by separating what the agent wants to show from how your application renders it. So I'll get into a little diagram here.
